alert.note: Alert for Central Panhandle Mountains; Northern Panhandle (Idaho) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Spokane (Eastern Washington and Northern Idaho)
info.headline: Winter Weather Advisory issued October 24 at 7:39AM MDT until October 26 at 12:00AM MDT by NWS Spokane
info.description: ...FIRST MODERATE SNOW EVENT FOR THE INLAND NORTHWEST ARRIVES TUESDAY AND WEDNESDAY... .Significant mountain snow accumulation above 3000 feet and measurable snow for lower elevations below 2500 feet. A robust and cold weather system will deliver mountain snow, lowland rain-snow, and colder overnight temperatures lingering through the remainder of the week. Mountain passes will be impacted by the heavy snowfall and lowland areas may see impacts to trees and sensitive vegetation from wet snow accumulation. ...WINTER WEATHER ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT FROM 11 PM THIS EVENING TO 11 PM PDT WEDNESDAY ESPECIALLY ELEVATIONS ABOVE 3000 FEET... * WHAT...Snow expected especially elevations above 3500 feet. Total snow accumulations between 4 to 8 inches above 3500 feet and a half an inch to 3 inches below 3500 feet. * WHERE...Lookout Pass, Mullan, Fourth Of July Pass, Athol, Sandpoint, Bonners Ferry, Eastport, Kellogg, Fernwood, Osburn, Wallace, Priest River, Clark Fork, Pinehurst, Schweitzer Mountain Road, St. Maries, and Dobson Pass. * WHEN...From 11 PM this evening to 11 PM PDT Wednesday. * IMPACTS...Plan on slippery road conditions. Travel may be challenging and difficult over mountain passes and high elevation roadways. These winter weather conditions could impact the Wednesday morning commute. Locations that see heavy wet snow could experience tree damage if they have not yet lost their leaves.
info.instruction: Slow down and use caution while traveling. The latest road conditions for the state you are calling from can be obtained by calling 5 1 1.
